## Asynchronous Javascript

### Synchronous code

Synchronous code in JavaScript is code that executes sequentially, one operation at a time, without waiting for external tasks to complete. In other words, each line of code is executed in order, and the program does not move to the next line until the current line has finished executing. This is the default behavior in JavaScript.

```
console.log("Start");
for (let i = 1; i <= 3; i++) {
  console.log(i);
}
console.log("End");
```

In this example, the code will execute line by line in the order it's written. The output will be:

```
Start
1
2
3
End
```

Each `console.log` statement is executed sequentially, and the loop runs to completion before moving on to the next line of code.

Synchronous code is straightforward and easy to reason about because you can predict the order in which statements will be executed. However, it also has the drawback of potentially blocking the main thread, which can lead to unresponsiveness in web applications when dealing with time-consuming tasks.

### Asynchronous code

Asynchronous code in JavaScript is code that allows certain tasks to be executed independently of the main program flow. It enables your program to continue running while waiting for potentially time-consuming operations to complete, such as fetching data from a server, reading a file, or handling user input. JavaScript provides various mechanisms for handling asynchronous code, including callbacks, Promises, and `async/await`.

<img src="data:image/png;base64," style="cursor:pointer;max-width:100%;" onclick="(function(img){if(img.wnd!=null&&!img.wnd.closed){img.wnd.focus();}else{var r=function(evt){if(evt.data=='ready'&&evt.source==img.wnd){img.wnd.postMessage(decodeURIComponent(img.getAttribute('src')),'*');window.removeEventListener('message',r);}};window.addEventListener('message',r);img.wnd=window.open('https://viewer.diagrams.net/?client=1&page=0&edit=_blank');}})(this);"/>

### The callback hell (pyramid of doom) problem

#### Using events and callback functions

A common need is to execute two or more asynchronous operations back to back, where each subsequent operation starts when the previous operation succeeds, with the result from the previous step. In the old days, doing several asynchronous operations in a row would lead to the classic callback pyramid of doom:

```
doSomething(function (result) {
  doSomethingElse(result, function (newResult) {
    doThirdThing(newResult, function (finalResult) {
      console.log(`Got the final result: ${finalResult}`);
    }, failureCallback);
  }, failureCallback);
}, failureCallback);
```

This way, we are heavely relying on events and callback functions to handle the asynchronous results. Events and callback functions can sometimes cause unpredictable results and make the code hard to read and maintain.

The continous trials to resolve this bothersome architecture gave birth to javascript Promises, that were a really good substitute and advancement to the "callback hell" problem. Using promises we can get rid of Events and callback functions, but the biggest advantage to using promises is that we can chain promises to produce a sequence of asynchronous operations, instead of nesting callback function and producing the "callback hell". Promises are an ES6 feature.

Here's the very same code written using javascript promises:

```
doSomething()
  .then(function (result) {
    return doSomethingElse(result);
  })
  .then(function (newResult) {
    return doThirdThing(newResult);
  })
  .then(function (finalResult) {
    console.log(`Got the final result: ${finalResult}`);
  })
  .catch(failureCallback);
```

With this pattern, you can create longer chains of processing, where each promise represents the completion of one asynchronous step in the chain. In addition, the arguments to `then` are optional, and `catch(failureCallback)` is short for `then(null, failureCallback)`  so if your error handling code is the same for all steps, you can attach it to the end of the chain.

Now for a more modern solution to chaining `.then()`, is the `Async/await` syntax, which is likewise a really good substitute and advancement to chaining promises using `.then()`, here's the same code written in `Async/await` syntax:

```
async function foo() {
  try {
    const result = await doSomething();
    const newResult = await doSomethingElse(result);
    const finalResult = await doThirdThing(newResult);
    console.log(`Got the final result: ${finalResult}`);
  } catch (error) {
    failureCallback(error);
  }
}
```
